title: Derivatives: Definition & Basic Rules
description: Cover derivative definition via difference quotient, derivative as slope and instantaneous rate of change, basic differentiation rules (power, constant, sum/difference), trig/exp/ln derivatives, and reading derivatives from graphs and tables.
goals: Define the derivative using the limit of a difference quotient and compute derivatives from the definition
Interpret the derivative as the slope of a tangent line and as an instantaneous rate of change
Apply power, constant, sum/difference, trig, exponential, and logarithmic differentiation rules fluently
Estimate and analyze derivatives from graphs and tables, including identifying points of non-differentiability
instructionalStrategy: Emphasize the limit definition first: students must understand what the derivative IS before memorizing shortcut rules.
Use multiple representations — algebraic, graphical, numerical, and verbal — since AP exams test all four.
Connect every derivative technique to its AP exam application: free-response questions demand justification, not just computation.
Build toward chain rule readiness: every basic rule learned here will be composed with the chain rule in Unit 3.

scaffold.title: The Derivative — Rates of Change & Tangent Lines
scaffold.content:
**The Big Idea:**

The derivative measures how fast a function is changing at a single instant. It transforms the average rate of change (slope of a secant line) into the instantaneous rate of change (slope of the tangent line) by taking a limit.

**Formal Definition:**

f'(x) = lim_{h→0} [f(x + h) − f(x)] / h

This is called the **difference quotient** form.

**Alternate Form (at a point x = a):**

f'(a) = lim_{x→a} [f(x) − f(a)] / (x − a)

**Interpretations:**
• **Geometric:** f'(a) is the slope of the tangent line to y = f(x) at x = a
• **Physical:** If s(t) is position, then s'(t) is velocity — the instantaneous rate of change of position
• **General:** f'(a) is the instantaneous rate of change of f with respect to x at x = a

**Tangent Line Equation:**
Given the point (a, f(a)) and slope m = f'(a):
y − f(a) = f'(a)(x − a)
scaffold.initialPrompt: What is the difference between the average rate of change of f on [a, b] and the instantaneous rate of change at x = a? How does the limit connect them?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Computing Derivatives from the Definition

examples.problem: Use the limit definition to find f'(x) for f(x) = x².
examples.solution:
**Apply the definition:** f'(x) = lim_{h→0} [f(x+h) − f(x)] / h

**Step 1 — Expand f(x+h):**
f(x+h) = (x+h)² = x² + 2xh + h²

**Step 2 — Compute the difference:**
f(x+h) − f(x) = x² + 2xh + h² − x² = 2xh + h²

**Step 3 — Form the quotient:**
[f(x+h) − f(x)] / h = (2xh + h²) / h = 2x + h

**Step 4 — Take the limit:**
f'(x) = lim_{h→0} (2x + h) = **2x**

So d/dx[x²] = 2x. The slope of y = x² at any point x is twice the x-coordinate.

examples.problem: Use the alternate form of the derivative to find f'(3) for f(x) = 1/x.
examples.solution:
**Alternate form:** f'(a) = lim_{x→a} [f(x) − f(a)] / (x − a)

**Step 1 — Set up with a = 3:**
f'(3) = lim_{x→3} [1/x − 1/3] / (x − 3)

**Step 2 — Combine the fraction in the numerator:**
= lim_{x→3} [(3 − x) / (3x)] / (x − 3)

**Step 3 — Simplify (note 3 − x = −(x − 3)):**
= lim_{x→3} [−(x − 3) / (3x)] / (x − 3)
= lim_{x→3} −1 / (3x)

**Step 4 — Evaluate:**
f'(3) = −1 / (3 · 3) = **−1/9**

**Check:** The general derivative of 1/x is −1/x², so f'(3) = −1/9 ✓

examples.problem: Use the limit definition to find f'(x) for f(x) = √x.
examples.solution:
**Apply the definition:** f'(x) = lim_{h→0} [√(x+h) − √x] / h

**Step 1 — Rationalize the numerator** (multiply by conjugate):
= lim_{h→0} [√(x+h) − √x] · [√(x+h) + √x] / [h · (√(x+h) + √x)]

**Step 2 — Simplify the numerator** (difference of squares):
= lim_{h→0} [(x+h) − x] / [h(√(x+h) + √x)]
= lim_{h→0} h / [h(√(x+h) + √x)]

**Step 3 — Cancel h:**
= lim_{h→0} 1 / (√(x+h) + √x)

**Step 4 — Evaluate:**
f'(x) = 1 / (√x + √x) = **1 / (2√x)**

**Key technique:** Rationalizing the numerator is the standard method for radical limits. You'll see this again in many AP problems.

scaffold.initialPrompt: In example 3, why did we multiply by the conjugate? What happens to the radical when you multiply (√a − √b)(√a + √b)?

scaffold.title: We-Do: Derivative Definition Practice

problems.question: Use the limit definition to find f'(x) for f(x) = 3x² + 2x.
hints: Expand f(x+h) = 3(x+h)² + 2(x+h) = 3x² + 6xh + 3h² + 2x + 2h. Subtract f(x) = 3x² + 2x to get 6xh + 3h² + 2h.
Divide by h: (6xh + 3h² + 2h)/h = 6x + 3h + 2. Take the limit as h → 0: f'(x) = 6x + 2.

problems.question: Use the alternate form of the derivative to find f'(4) for f(x) = √x.
hints: Set up: f'(4) = lim_{x→4} [√x − 2] / (x − 4). Rationalize the numerator by multiplying by (√x + 2)/(√x + 2).

problems.question: Use the limit definition to find f'(x) for f(x) = 1/(x + 1).
hints: Compute f(x+h) − f(x) = 1/(x+h+1) − 1/(x+1). Find a common denominator: [(x+1) − (x+h+1)] / [(x+h+1)(x+1)] = −h / [(x+h+1)(x+1)].
Divide by h: −1/[(x+h+1)(x+1)]. Take the limit as h → 0: f'(x) = −1/(x+1)².

scaffold.initialPrompt: For the first problem, start by expanding f(x+h) = 3(x+h)² + 2(x+h). What do you get?

scaffold.title: Basic Differentiation Rules
scaffold.content:
**The limit definition works but is slow. These rules let you differentiate instantly:**

**Constant Rule:** d/dx[c] = 0

**Power Rule:** d/dx[x^n] = nx^(n−1) — works for ALL real exponents (integer, fractional, negative)

**Constant Multiple:** d/dx[cf(x)] = c · f'(x)

**Sum/Difference:** d/dx[f(x) ± g(x)] = f'(x) ± g'(x)

**Trig Derivatives:**
• d/dx[sin x] = cos x
• d/dx[cos x] = −sin x
• d/dx[tan x] = sec²x
• d/dx[csc x] = −csc x · cot x
• d/dx[sec x] = sec x · tan x
• d/dx[cot x] = −csc²x

**Exponential & Logarithmic:**
• d/dx[e^x] = e^x
• d/dx[ln x] = 1/x
• d/dx[a^x] = a^x · ln a

**Key Strategy:** Before differentiating, ALWAYS rewrite radicals and fractions as power expressions:
• √x = x^(1/2), 1/x² = x^(−2), ³√x = x^(1/3), 5/x = 5x^(−1)
scaffold.initialPrompt: Rewrite f(x) = 4/x³ + 3√x − 2/√x using exponent notation so the power rule applies directly.

scaffold.title: I-Do: Applying Differentiation Rules

examples.solution:
**Step 1 — Rewrite using exponents:**
f(x) = 5x³ − 2x⁻² + 3x^(1/2) − 7

**Step 2 — Apply the power rule term by term:**
• d/dx[5x³] = 5 · 3x² = 15x²
• d/dx[−2x⁻²] = −2 · (−2)x⁻³ = 4x⁻³
• d/dx[3x^(1/2)] = 3 · (1/2)x^(−1/2) = (3/2)x^(−1/2)
• d/dx[−7] = 0

**Step 3 — Combine:**
f'(x) = 15x² + 4x⁻³ + (3/2)x^(−1/2)

**Rewrite in standard form:**
f'(x) = **15x² + 4/x³ + 3/(2√x)**

**Key lesson:** Rewriting as power expressions first makes the power rule apply to every term — no quotient rule needed.

**Apply the rules term by term:**
• d/dx[3sin x] = 3cos x
• d/dx[−4cos x] = −4(−sin x) = 4sin x
• d/dx[2e^x] = 2e^x
• d/dx[−5ln x] = −5 · (1/x) = −5/x

**Combine:**
f'(x) = **3cos(x) + 4sin(x) + 2e^x − 5/x**

**Notice:** Each trig/exp/ln rule is just a memorized fact. The sum/difference rule lets you differentiate term by term. These rules will combine with the chain rule in Unit 3 for compositions like sin(3x) or e^(2x).

examples.problem: Find the equation of the tangent line to f(x) = x³ − 2x + 1 at x = 2.
examples.solution:
**Step 1 — Find the y-coordinate (the point):**
f(2) = (2)³ − 2(2) + 1 = 8 − 4 + 1 = **5**
Point: (2, 5)

**Step 2 — Find the slope (differentiate):**
f'(x) = 3x² − 2
f'(2) = 3(2)² − 2 = 12 − 2 = **10**

**Step 3 — Write the tangent line (point-slope form):**
y − 5 = 10(x − 2)
y = 10x − 20 + 5
y = **10x − 15**

**AP exam note:** Tangent line questions appear constantly. The three-step process — find the point, find the slope, write the equation — is the standard approach.

scaffold.initialPrompt: In example 1, what would happen if you tried to differentiate 2/x² directly without rewriting as 2x⁻²? What rule would you need?

scaffold.title: We-Do: Differentiation Rules Practice

problems.question: Find f'(x) for f(x) = 4x⁵ − 3/x + 7√x − 2.
hints: Rewrite: f(x) = 4x⁵ − 3x⁻¹ + 7x^(1/2) − 2. Apply the power rule to each term.

problems.question: Find f'(x) for f(x) = 2sin(x) − 3e^x + 4ln(x) + tan(x).
hints: Apply the rules term by term: d/dx[sin x] = cos x, d/dx[e^x] = e^x, d/dx[ln x] = 1/x, d/dx[tan x] = sec²x.
f'(x) = 2cos(x) − 3e^x + 4/x + sec²(x).

problems.question: Find the equation of the tangent line to f(x) = e^x + sin(x) at x = 0.
hints: Find f(0) = e⁰ + sin(0) = 1 + 0 = 1. Find f'(x) = e^x + cos(x), then f'(0) = 1 + 1 = 2.
Point: (0, 1). Slope: 2. Tangent: y − 1 = 2(x − 0), so y = 2x + 1.

scaffold.title: Derivatives from Graphs & Tables
scaffold.content:
**AP Calculus tests derivatives in ALL representations — not just algebraic.**

**Estimating f'(a) from a Table:**
If you don't have a formula but have data points, use the **symmetric difference quotient**:
f'(a) ≈ [f(a + h) − f(a − h)] / (2h)
This uses one point on each side of a and gives a better estimate than a one-sided quotient.

**Reading f' from a Graph of f:**
• Where f is increasing → f' > 0
• Where f is decreasing → f' < 0
• Where f has a horizontal tangent (local max/min) → f' = 0
• Steeper slope on f → larger |f'|
• If f is a line segment with slope m → f' = m (constant) on that interval

**Differentiability:**
f is differentiable at x = a if and only if f'(a) exists (the limit definition gives a finite value). Differentiability REQUIRES continuity, but continuity does NOT guarantee differentiability.

**f is NOT differentiable at:**
• **Corners** (sharp turns) — left and right slopes exist but differ
• **Cusps** — slopes approach +∞ and −∞ from opposite sides
• **Vertical tangents** — slope approaches ±∞
• **Discontinuities** — function not continuous, so not differentiable
scaffold.initialPrompt: If a function f is continuous at x = 3 but has a corner there, does f'(3) exist? Why or why not?

scaffold.title: I-Do: Graphical & Tabular Derivatives

examples.problem:
The table shows selected values of a differentiable function f:
| x | 1.0 | 1.5 | 2.0 | 2.5 | 3.0 |
| f(x) | 3.0 | 4.1 | 5.4 | 6.9 | 8.6 |
Estimate f'(2.0) using the symmetric difference quotient.
examples.solution:
**Symmetric difference quotient:** Use the points on both sides of x = 2.0:

f'(2.0) ≈ [f(2.5) − f(1.5)] / (2.5 − 1.5)
= (6.9 − 4.1) / 1.0
= **2.8**

**Why symmetric?** Compare with one-sided estimates:
• Forward: [f(2.5) − f(2.0)] / 0.5 = (6.9 − 5.4) / 0.5 = 3.0
• Backward: [f(2.0) − f(1.5)] / 0.5 = (5.4 − 4.1) / 0.5 = 2.6

The symmetric quotient (2.8) averages these and is the **AP-preferred method** when data is available on both sides.

examples.problem: A continuous function h is defined on [−2, 6]. From its graph: h is smooth on (−2, 1), has a sharp corner at x = 1, is smooth on (1, 3), has a cusp at x = 3, is smooth on (3, 5), has a vertical tangent at x = 5, and is smooth on (5, 6). At which points in (−2, 6) is h not differentiable?
examples.solution:
**Check each candidate:**

**x = 1 (corner):** The left-hand slope and right-hand slope both exist but are NOT equal. The limit definition gives two different one-sided limits → **h'(1) does not exist** ✗

**x = 3 (cusp):** The slopes approach +∞ from one side and −∞ from the other. The limit is not finite → **h'(3) does not exist** ✗

**x = 5 (vertical tangent):** The tangent line is vertical, meaning the slope approaches ±∞. The limit is not finite → **h'(5) does not exist** ✗

**Answer: h is not differentiable at x = 1, x = 3, and x = 5.**

**Key point:** h is continuous at all three points — continuity is necessary but NOT sufficient for differentiability.

examples.problem: The graph of f on [−4, 4] consists of three line segments: from (−4, 2) to (−1, 5), from (−1, 5) to (1, 5), and from (1, 5) to (4, −1). Describe the graph of f'.
examples.solution:
**Find the slope of each segment:**

**Segment 1: (−4, 2) to (−1, 5)**
Slope = (5 − 2) / (−1 − (−4)) = 3/3 = **1**

**Segment 2: (−1, 5) to (1, 5)**
Slope = (5 − 5) / (1 − (−1)) = 0/2 = **0**

**Segment 3: (1, 5) to (4, −1)**
Slope = (−1 − 5) / (4 − 1) = −6/3 = **−2**

**f'(x) is a piecewise constant function:**
• f'(x) = 1 for −4 < x < −1
• f'(x) = 0 for −1 < x < 1
• f'(x) = −2 for 1 < x < 4
• f'(−1) and f'(1) do not exist (corners)

**Pattern:** When f is made of line segments, f' is a step function. Where f is increasing → f' > 0. Where f is flat → f' = 0. Where f is decreasing → f' < 0.

scaffold.initialPrompt: In example 3, why does f' not exist at x = −1 and x = 1? What happens to the slope at those transition points?

scaffold.title: We-Do: Graph & Table Practice

problems.question:
The table shows selected values of a differentiable function f:
| x | 0 | 2 | 4 | 6 | 8 |
| f(x) | 5 | 8 | 13 | 15 | 16 |
Estimate f'(4) using the symmetric difference quotient.
hints: Use the symmetric difference quotient with the points on both sides of x = 4: f'(4) ≈ [f(6) − f(2)] / (6 − 2).

problems.question: A continuous function g has a sharp corner at x = 2 and a vertical tangent at x = 5. Everywhere else on [0, 7], g is smooth. At which x-values in (0, 7) is g not differentiable?
hints: Differentiability fails at corners, cusps, vertical tangents, and discontinuities.
g has a corner at x = 2 (left and right slopes differ) and a vertical tangent at x = 5 (slope approaches ±∞). So g is not differentiable at x = 2 and x = 5.

problems.question: The graph of g on [−2, 6] consists of a line segment from (−2, 5) to (1, −1) and a line segment from (1, −1) to (6, 9). Describe g'(x) on (−2, 6).
problems.answer: g'(x) = −2 for −2 < x < 1, g'(x) = 2 for 1 < x < 6, g'(1) does not exist (corner).
hints: Find the slope of each segment. From (−2, 5) to (1, −1): slope = (−1 − 5) / (1 − (−2)) = −6/3 = −2.
From (1, −1) to (6, 9): slope = (9 − (−1)) / (6 − 1) = 10/5 = 2. So g'(x) = −2 for −2 < x < 1 and g'(x) = 2 for 1 < x < 6. g'(1) DNE because the left slope (−2) ≠ right slope (2).

scaffold.initialPrompt: For the first problem, which two table values do you use for the symmetric difference quotient centered at x = 4?

problems.question: Use the limit definition to find f'(x) for f(x) = x² − 4x.
hints: Expand: f(x+h) = (x+h)² − 4(x+h) = x² + 2xh + h² − 4x − 4h. Subtract f(x) = x² − 4x to get 2xh + h² − 4h.
Divide by h: 2x + h − 4. Take the limit as h → 0: f'(x) = 2x − 4.

problems.question: Find f'(x) for f(x) = 6x^(2/3) − x⁴ + 5/x.
hints: Rewrite 5/x as 5x⁻¹. Apply the power rule to each term: d/dx[6x^(2/3)] = 6·(2/3)x^(−1/3) = 4x^(−1/3).
d/dx[−x⁴] = −4x³. d/dx[5x⁻¹] = −5x⁻². Combine: f'(x) = 4x^(−1/3) − 4x³ − 5x⁻².

problems.question: Find f'(x) for f(x) = 3cos(x) + 5e^x − 2/x + tan(x).
hints: Rewrite −2/x as −2x⁻¹. Apply rules term by term: d/dx[cos x] = −sin x, d/dx[e^x] = e^x, d/dx[x⁻¹] = −x⁻², d/dx[tan x] = sec²x.
f'(x) = −3sin(x) + 5e^x + 2x⁻² + sec²(x) = −3sin(x) + 5e^x + 2/x² + sec²(x).

problems.question: Find the equation of the tangent line to f(x) = ln(x) + x² at x = 1.
hints: Point: (1, 1). Slope: 3. Tangent: y − 1 = 3(x − 1), so y = 3x − 2.

problems.question:
The table shows selected values of a differentiable function f:
| x | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6 | 7 |
| f(x) | 12 | 10 | 9 | 7 | 3 |
Estimate f'(5) using the symmetric difference quotient.
hints: Symmetric difference quotient: f'(5) ≈ [f(6) − f(4)] / (6 − 4).

problems.question: The graph of f on [0, 6] consists of a line segment from (0, 3) to (2, 7) and a line segment from (2, 7) to (6, −1). Find f'(1), f'(4), and determine whether f'(2) exists.
problems.answer: f'(1) = 2, f'(4) = −2, f'(2) does not exist (corner).
hints: Find the slope of each segment: (0, 3) to (2, 7) has slope (7−3)/(2−0) = 2. (2, 7) to (6, −1) has slope (−1−7)/(6−2) = −2.
f'(1) = 2 (on first segment). f'(4) = −2 (on second segment). At x = 2, left derivative = 2 ≠ right derivative = −2, so f'(2) does not exist (corner).
